title: 110_s1881
content: The Act may be cited as the "Americans with Disabilities Act Restoration Act of 2007". Congress finds that the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 was intended to establish a clear prohibition of discrimination based on disability, provide broad coverage, and effective remedies. However, Supreme Court decisions have narrowed the scope of protection, excluding individuals Congress aimed to protect. Disabilities are seen as natural parts of human experience that should not limit participation in all aspects of life. Congress recognized that disabilities are natural parts of the human experience and should not limit participation in society. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 was modeled after the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 to encompass both actual and perceived limitations imposed by society. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 broadened the definition of disability to include actual and perceived limitations, as well as those imposed by society. This concept was underscored by the Supreme Court's decision in School Board of Nassau County v. Arline, acknowledging that societal myths and fears about disability can be as limiting as physical impairments. Congress understood that adverse actions based on physical or mental impairments are often unrelated to the limitations caused by the impairment itself. The Supreme Court has interpreted the term "disability" strictly, creating a demanding standard for qualification as disabled, contrary to congressional expectations in the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The Supreme Court has narrowed the coverage of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 by excluding individuals who have mitigated their impairments. The Act aims to restore broad protection and address Supreme Court decisions that have limited its scope. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 has been narrowed by Supreme Court decisions, excluding individuals who have mitigated their impairments. The Act aims to reinstate broad protection for all individuals affected by adverse treatment based on impairment. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 aims to protect individuals from adverse treatment based on impairment, including prejudiced attitudes and societal barriers. FINDINGS IN AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT OF 1990. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 emphasizes that individuals with disabilities have the right to fully participate in society and have historically faced discrimination. Individuals with disabilities have faced purposeful unequal treatment, restrictions, and political powerlessness in society. Classifications excluding them should be strongly disfavored and only permitted for compelling reasons, not based on prejudice or stereotypes about disability. The definition of disability is outlined in Section 4. Individuals with disabilities have historically faced discrimination and exclusion in society, and classifications excluding them should only be allowed for compelling reasons, not based on prejudice or stereotypes. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. 12102) defines disability as a physical or mental impairment, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having an impairment. The determination of impairment should not consider the use of mitigating measures. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 defines disability as a physical or mental impairment, without regard to the use of mitigating measures. Mitigating measures refer to treatments or devices used to lessen the impact of an impairment. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 defines disability as a physical or mental impairment, without regard to the use of mitigating measures. Mitigating measures refer to treatments or devices used to lessen the impact of an impairment. The term 'mental impairment' refers to any mental or psychological disorder, while 'physical impairment' refers to any physiological disorder. The term 'physical impairment' refers to any physiological disorder, cosmetic disfigurement, or anatomical loss affecting various body systems. 'Record of a physical or mental impairment' means a history of or misclassification as having such an impairment. The term 'regarded as having a physical or mental impairment' means perceived or treated as having such an impairment, regardless of the actual presence of an impairment. SEC. 5. ADVERSE ACTION. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to include discrimination against individuals using mitigating measures or experiencing side effects as discrimination under this Act. SEC. 6. DISCRIMINATION ON THE BASIS OF DISABILITY. SEC. 6 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to prohibit discrimination on the basis of disability. This includes removing language that specifies discrimination against a qualified individual with a disability and instead focuses on discrimination against an individual on the basis of disability. Section 501 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to ensure broad construction of the Act for comprehensive prohibition of discrimination based on disability. Regulations are to be issued by the Attorney General, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and Secretary of Transportation within 180 days to implement various sections of the Act. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to broaden the prohibition of discrimination based on disability. Regulations will be issued by various agencies to implement the provisions of the Act. The Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board will issue supplementary guidelines to supplement existing accessibility requirements. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to broaden the prohibition of discrimination based on disability. Duly issued Federal regulations and guidance for the implementation of the Act shall be entitled to deference by administrative agencies, officers, and courts in any action brought under this Act.
